DataElement.preferredName: Patient Metastatic Malignant Neoplasm to the Brain Exclusion Criteria Ind-2
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the yes/no indicator related to the status of brain metastasis, as a medical characteristic prevents a subject from being allowed to participate in a clinical study, as outlined in the study protocol.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Patient Metastatic Malignant Neoplasm to the Brain Exclusion Criteria
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to the status of brain metastasis, neoplasm that have spread from a primary site to the brain of a patient or participant as a medical and/or social characteristic that prevents a subject from being allowed to participate in a clinical study, as outlined in the study protocol.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A person who requires medical care.

Concepts.definition: A person who receives medical attention, care, or treatment, or who is registered with medical professional or institution with the purpose to receive medical care when necessary.

Property.preferredName: Metastatic Malignant Neoplasm to the Brain Exclusion Criteria
Property.preferredDefinition: The spread of a neoplasm from a primary site to the brain. The most common primary tumors metastatic to brain include lung cancer(adenosquamous and small cell especially), breast cancer, melanoma, renal cancer and colon cancer. Metastases are frequently found at the grey/white junction. They are usually well demarcated from the brain parenchyma. The majority of metastases (greater than 75%) are found supratentorially with the minority (less than 10%) found in the brainstem. The patients present with signs and symptoms referable to either increased intracranial pressure or focal pathology. A contrast enhanced MRI will give the best view of suspected metastatic cancers. Therapy for the metastatic cancer is based upon the therapy that would be or has been given to the primary cancer. In any event corticosteroids can be useful for reduction of patients' symptoms. (Kaye, Laws Brain Tumors Churchill Livingstone 1995):Exclusion; the act of restricting entrance or barring from participation.

Concepts.longName: Metastatic Malignant Neoplasm in the Brain
Concepts.definition: A malignant neoplasm that has spread to the brain from another anatomic site or system. The majority are carcinomas (usually lung or breast carcinomas).
Medical and/or social characteristics that prevent a subject from being allowed to participate in a clinical study, as outlined in the study protocol.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: trial-specific criteria that a patient must meet to be enrolled.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The preferred Value Domain to indicate a question with permissible values of yes/no.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The non-affirmative response to a question.

Concepts.definition: The non-affirmative response to a question.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The affirmative response to a question.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Conceptual domain that includes value meanings to be used for Indicator Value Meanings such as Yes, No, Unknown, No Applicable

Concepts.definition: A response or indicator that can have a value of either yes or no.

ReferenceDocuments.name: Evidence of active brain meta
ReferenceDocuments.description: Evidence of active brain metastasis including leptomeningeal involvement. CNS metastasis controlled by prior surgery and/or radiotherapy is allowed.

ReferenceDocuments.name: CRF Text3
ReferenceDocuments.description: Uncontrolled brain metastases including patients who continue to require glucocorticoids for brain or leptomeningeal metastases

ReferenceDocuments.name: CRF Text 4
ReferenceDocuments.description: Extensive active brain disease, including symptomatic brain metastases or the presence of leptomeningeal disease.

ReferenceDocuments.name: NRG_CRF text
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does the patient have known brain metastases or leptomeningeal metastases?

ReferenceDocuments.name: CITN
ReferenceDocuments.description: Extensive active brain disease including symptomatic brain metastases or presence of leptomeningeal disease (Note: Patients with brain metastasis, after definitive therapy with surgery or stereotactic radiation and stable off steroids for >= 4 weeks, are eligible.)

ReferenceDocuments.name: NRG_CRF text 1
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does the patient have untreated brain metastases, spinal cord compression, or evidence of symptomatic brain metastases or leptomeningeal disease as noted on CT or MRI?

ReferenceDocuments.name: NRG CRF Text2
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does the patient have known brain metastases or central nervous system metastases or history of uncontrolled seizures?

ReferenceDocuments.name: NRG CRF_Text 3
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does the patient have active central nervous system (CNS) or leptomeningeal metastasis (brain metastasis) at the time of enrollment

ReferenceDocuments.name: CRF Text 5
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does the patient have symptomatic uncontrolled brain metastases requiring corticosteroid treatment?

ReferenceDocuments.name: CRF Text6
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does the patient have untreated brain metastases?

ReferenceDocuments.name: CRF Text7
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does the patient have symptomatic leptomeningeal disease, or known brain metastases?
